{{for|the private university in Ukraine|International Christian University – Kiev}} {{Use mdy dates|date=October 2011}} {{Infobox university | name = International Christian University | native_name = 国際基督教大学 | image = ICU japan.jpg | motto =Expanding Potential | established = June 15, 1949 | type = [[Private university|Private]], [[Liberal Arts College]] | affiliation = [[Nondenominational Christianity|Non-denominational]], [[Ecumenism|Ecumenical]], [[Alliance of Asian Liberal Arts Universities|AALAU]], [[Global Liberal Arts Alliance|GLAA]] | head_label = President | head = Dr. [[Junko Hibiya]] | undergrad = 2,934 | postgrad = 237 | city = [[Mitaka, Tokyo|Mitaka]] | state = [[Tokyo]] | country = {{flag|Japan}} | campus = Suburban; 153 wooden acres | language = [[Japanese language|Japanese]]; [[English language|English]] | nickname= ICU | website = [http://www.icu.ac.jp www.icu.ac.jp] | faculty = 147 }} [[File:Icu_maingate_20100624.jpg|260px|thumb|right|The Front Gate of ICU]] {{nihongo|'''International Christian University''' |国際基督教大学|Kokusai Kirisutokyō Daigaku|'''ICU'''}} is a non-denominational [[private university]] located in [[Mitaka, Tokyo]], [[Japan]]. Commonly known as '''ICU''' (in Japan and abroad), the university was founded in 1949. ICU offers 31 undergraduate majors and a [[Graduate school]]. The university is considered to be the most prestigious [[Liberal arts college|Liberal Arts College]] in Japan and it has several partner institutions worldwide including [[University of California|The University of California system]], [[University of Pennsylvania]], [[Duke University]], [[Yonsei University]], [[University College London]] and more. ICU is unique for being a fully bilingual campus. Classes are held in either English or Japanese, with all faculty required to have strong command in both languages. https://www.icu.ac.jp/en/campuslife/club/bilingual.html Notable alumni include: [[Princess Mako of Akishino]], [[Princess Kako of Akishino]], President and CEO of [[Sony]], [[Kaz Hirai]], and U.S. Senator, [[Jay Rockefeller]]. In 2014, the [[Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology]] selected ICU as one of the 37 schools for [[Top Global University Project|The Top Global University Project]]. It is consistently ranked as one of the top and most selective universities in Japan. ==Institution== {{refimprove section|date=December 2011}} ===History=== [[File:International Christian University in 1950s.JPG|thumb|International Christian University in 1950s. The main building was used by Mitaka Institute of the [[Nakajima Aircraft Company]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ne.jp/asahi/airplane/museum/nakajima/nakajima2.html|title=中島飛行機株式会社その軌跡|accessdate=May 24, 2010|language=Japanese}}]] ICU was founded in 1949. With an emphasis on reconciliation and peace, ICU was envisaged as a “University of Tomorrow,” a place where [[Japanese people|Japanese]] and international students would live together and learn to serve the needs of an emerging, more interconnected world. When students enter ICU they sign the [[United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights]]{{cite web|url=http://www.icu.ac.jp/en/about/pledge.html|title=Student Pledge - ICU - INTERNATIONAL CHRISTIAN UNIVERSITY|publisher=|accessdate=July 29, 2016}} and they are challenged to commit themselves to help bring about social justice and world peace. Due to this commitment to human rights, [[Eleanor Roosevelt]] delivered ICU's first convocation address. According to JICUF (Japan ICU Foundation),
"Concerted fundraising campaigns were initiated in both [[Japan]] and in [[North America]]. [[Hisato Ichimada]], the Governor of the [[Bank of Japan]] who was [[Buddhism in Japan|Buddhist]], headed the Japan campaign that raised the funds necessary to purchase a large tract of land for the university. The Honorary Chair of the US fundraising campaign was General [[Douglas MacArthur]], and the North American public responded with generous contributions as well."[http://www.jicuf.org/history History - Japan ICU Foundation]
The third son of the [[Emperor Taishō]], a younger brother of the [[Hirohito|Emperor Shōwa]] and an uncle of the [[Emperor of Japan|Emperor]] [[Akihito]] [[Nobuhito, Prince Takamatsu]] officiated the Honorary President of the Preparatory Committee for founding ICU. File:Takamatsunomiya nobuhito.jpg|[[Nobuhito, Prince Takamatsu]], Honorary President of the Preparatory Committee for founding ICU File:MacArthur(2).jpg|General [[Douglas MacArthur]], Honorary Chair of the US fundraising campaign File:Hachiro Yuasa 01.jpg| Hachiro Yuasa ([[:ja:湯浅八郎|ja]]), first President of ICU ==Campus== ICU's main campus of 150 wooded acres is located in west Tokyo, with downtown areas like Shinjuku about half an hour's train ride away. Computer and internet access is available throughout the campus. [[File:Entrance to ICU in spring.jpg|thumb|The entrance to ICU leading up to the university chapel. The road has rows of cherry blossom trees on both side which bloom in spring, signifying the start of a new school year.]] The campus sits on ancient pre-[[Jomon]] and Jomon archaeological remains, which gives students the opportunity to participate in archaeological fieldwork. Excavated items found on the campus are on permanent display in the [[Hachiro Yuasa Memorial Museum]]. In addition, the campus is directly on the former location of a [[Nakajima Aircraft Company]] factory. In a quiet wooded area of the campus and through a large thatched gate is the Taizanso Garden. Built in the 1920s, the garden includes a traditional Japanese [[tea house]] and the historically significant One-Mat Room constructed out of wood gathered from sacred and historic sites throughout Japan. ICU owns a {{convert|240|acre|km2|adj=on}} campus in Nasu and a {{convert|13|acre|m2|adj=on}} retreat center in [[Karuizawa, Nagano|Karuizawa]], [[Kitasaku District, Nagano|Kitasaku District]], [[Nagano Prefecture]]. ICU houses one of the Rotary Centers for [[International studies|International Studies]] in [[Peace and conflict studies|peace and conflict resolution]], partnering with [[Rotary International]]. The [[University of California]] Tokyo Study Center which hosts the UCEAP program to Japan is also located on ICU campus.{{Cite web|url=http://www.uctsc.org/index.html|title=University of California Tokyo Study Center, EAP, Japan Program, Sign Out, UC Center, カリフォルニア大学東京スタディセンター|website=www.uctsc.org|access-date=2018-02-03}} File:International Christian University, Mitaka, Tokyo, Japan.jpg|The exterior of the main building including the classrooms, laboratories and clinics was changed in 2003. File:International Christian University Church.jpg|The entrance ceremonies and the graduation ceremonies are held in the ICU Chapel. File:International Christian University Bicycles Parking Area.jpg|There are students who ride bicycles on the wide ICU campus. ==Academics== ICU offers [[bachelor's degree]]s in [[Bachelor of Liberal Arts|liberal arts]] fields, as well as [[master's degree|master's]] and [[doctorate|doctoral]] [[academic degree|degree]]s in [[education]], [[public administration]], comparative culture and [[natural science]]s. About 18% of the faculty come from overseas (primarily [[English-speaking world|English-speaking countries]]). There is a strong English language program (ELP), taught by tenured and contract faculty English teachers, which was embroiled in a contentious curricular reform in 2010{{cite web |url=http://web.icu.ac.jp/lrb/docs/HaleLRB25.pdf |format=PDF |last=Hale |first=C. |year=2010 |title= Change, Conflict and Conant: ELP Reform and ICU's Liberal Arts Heritage. Language research bulletin. 25 |location=Tokyo |publisher=International Christian University}} leading to the name being changed to the ELA (English for Liberal Arts program) in April 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.icu.ac.jp/english/liberalarts/collegewide/elp/index.html|title=HTTP 404 error｜国際基督教大学|publisher=|accessdate=July 29, 2016}} Academics who aspire to teach at ICU are required to submit a reference who can testify to their commitment to Christianity, despite the university' stance that increasing adherents to the Christian faith is not its primary goal.[http://www.icu.ac.jp/en/about/commitment.html] === Undergraduate Programs === Students choose one or two majors as single major, double major or major/minor. 31 majors are being offered as of 2017.{{cite web|url=http://www.icu.ac.jp/english/liberalarts/major/index.html|title=HTTP 404 error｜国際基督教大学|publisher=|accessdate=July 29, 2016}} * [[American studies|American Studies]] * [[Anthropology]] * [[Arts]] and [[Archaeology]] * [[Asian studies|Asian Studies]] * [[Biology]] * [[Business]] * [[Chemistry]] * [[Computer science|Computer Science]] * [[Development studies|Development Studies]] * [[Economics]] * [[Education]] * [[Environmental studies|Environmental Studies]] * [[Gender studies|Gender and Sexuality Studies]] * [[Global studies|Global Studies]] * [[International relations theory|International Relations]] * [[Japanese studies|Japan Studies]] * [[Language education|Language Education]] * [[Law]] * [[Linguistics]] * [[Literature]] * [[Mathematics]] * [[Media (communication)|Media]], [[Communication]] and [[Culture]] * [[Music]] * [[Peace and conflict studies|Peace Studies]] * [[Philosophy]] and [[Religion]] * [[Physics]] * [[Politics]] * [[Psychology]] * [[Public policy|Public Policy]] * [[Sociology]] === Graduate Programs{{Cite web|url=https://www.icu.ac.jp/en/gs/ma/index.html|title=Master’s course {{!}} ICU - INTERNATIONAL CHRISTIAN UNIVERSITY|website=www.icu.ac.jp|access-date=2018-02-03}} === * [[Master of Arts in Education]] ** Concentrations: Education, Psychology, or Language Education * Master of Arts in [[Public administration|Public Administration]] or Master of Arts in [[International relations|International Relations]] * Master of Arts in Social and [[Cultural analysis|Cultural Analysis]] * Master of Arts in [[Media (communication)|Media]] and [[Language]] * Master of Arts in [[Public economics|Public Economics]] * Master of Arts in [[Peace Studies]] * Master of Arts in [[Comparative cultural studies|Comparative Culture]] ** Concentrations: Japanese Culture Studies or Transcultural Studies * Master of Arts in [[Natural science|Natural Sciences]] ** Concentrations: Mathematics and Information Science, Material Science, or Life Science === Bilingual Academics === The languages of instruction at ICU are Japanese and English. Around 30% of all courses are offered in English, the rest in Japanese or in both languages.{{Cite web|url=https://www.icu.ac.jp/en/admissions/september/faq/index.html#g5|title=FAQ {{!}} ICU - INTERNATIONAL CHRISTIAN UNIVERSITY|website=www.icu.ac.jp|access-date=2018-01-18}} Prospective students without prior Japanese language knowledge are able to apply under a documentary screening process, instead of undergoing the entrance exams held in Japanese. These students are required to have college level English proficiency and subsequently take ICU Japanese Language Programs (JLP) courses to gain [[Multilingualism|bilingualism]] and eventually take courses taught in Japanese.{{Cite web|url=https://www.icu.ac.jp/en/admissions/september/faq/index.html#g2|title=FAQ {{!}} ICU - INTERNATIONAL CHRISTIAN UNIVERSITY|website=www.icu.ac.jp|access-date=2018-01-18}} Under the policy of [[Multilingualism|bilingualism]] of ICU curriculum, students take language courses for their non-dominant language in their freshman and sophomore year (Depending on the student's language requirements, English for Liberal Arts or Japanese Language Programs).{{Cite web|url=https://www.icu.ac.jp/en/liberalarts/policy/index.html|title=Policies {{!}} ICU - INTERNATIONAL CHRISTIAN UNIVERSITY|website=www.icu.ac.jp|access-date=2018-01-18}} Each campus department staffs employees with strong command in both languages. Student resources, ICU websites, and campus bulletin boards are in both Japanese and English to accommodate students from any language background.{{Cite web|url=https://www.icu.ac.jp/en/campuslife/club/bilingual.html|title=A Fully Bilingual Campus Organizational Structure {{!}} ICU - INTERNATIONAL CHRISTIAN UNIVERSITY|website=www.icu.ac.jp|access-date=2018-01-18}} === Trimester System === The academic year is divided into trimesters of approximately eleven weeks each with each course lasting one trimester term. This allows for a dynamic learning experience, one where students can design their own curricula as their interests change and develop. ===Japan ICU Foundation=== The Japan ICU Foundation (JICUF){{cite web|url=http://www.jicuf.org|title=Home Cover Page|publisher=|accessdate=July 29, 2016}} was incorporated in [[New York (state)|New York State]] on November 23, 1948 and helped to establish ICU in 1953. Today, the foundation maintains two [[Nonprofit organization|non-profit corporations]]: The Japan ICU Foundation, Inc. and the JICUF Endowment, Inc. The Japan ICU Foundation supports ICU in a variety of ways, including providing scholarships, running a faculty exchange program, providing funding for international programs and projects and helping to fund new buildings on campus. The Foundation has offices in [[New York City]]. The current president of JICUF is Dr. David Vikner. == Research Institutes == ICU has eight research institutes as of 2016. In addition to research, these institutes plan and sponsor conferences, lectures, symposia and seminars as well as provide students with opportunities to meet distinguished scholars from Japan and overseas. * The Institute of Educational Research and Service (IERS) * The Social Science Research Institute (SSRI) * The Institute for the Study of Christianity and Culture (ICC) * The Institute of Asian Cultural Studies (IACS) * The Peace Research Institute (PRI) * The Research Center for Japanese Language Education (RCJLE) * The Institute for Advanced Studies of Clinical Psychology (IASCP) * The Center for Gender Studies (CGS) ==Student life== ===Demographics=== As of 2011, ICU had 2851 undergraduates studying in the College of Liberal Arts, with a 1041 male students and 1810 female students. The ICU Graduate School had 150 students, with 64 men and 86 women. 90.5% of ICU's undergraduate and graduate students are Japanese citizens, and the remainder represent 44 countries. Many returnee Japanese students that have lived overseas, also known as [[kikokushijo]] (帰国子女), make up the student body.https://www.icu.ac.jp/en//about/info/outline/Student.html The majority of ICU students live off-campus, either at home with their families or in apartments. As of 2010, about 600 students were living on campus. === International Education Exchange Programs === More than half of the students participate in study abroad programs during their time at ICU. The percentage of students who study abroad through ICU programs before they graduate is 55.5% (in 2014). Students who come from abroad to study at ICU on a year-long exchange program are referred to as OYRs (One Year Regulars). ===ICU Dining Hall=== The ICU Dining Hall, also known as Gakki (ガッキ), is the official cafeteria of International Christian University. Rebuilt in 2010, Gakki is a public, self-service [[cafeteria]] and is one of the newest and most renowned buildings on campus. ===Student clubs/circles=== ICU students are known for their remarkable energy and initiative in creating a kaleidoscope of student-led and student-managed co-curricular activities. There are about 100 student-led clubs and organizations in the arts, sports, academic and social fields. New clubs are formed as student interest dictates, and most ICU students participate in one or more of these organizations. === After Graduation === As of 2016, 95.3% of ICU undergraduate alumni (students seeking employment) land a job right after graduation.{{Cite web|url=http://www.icu.ac.jp/en/campuslife/career/index.html|title=Paths after Graduation|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}} ICU students have found employment in a wide range of industries, particularly with global companies. Over 20% of students go on to graduate school overseas and in Japan. Domestic and Overseas Universities include: International Christian University, [[University of Tokyo]], [[Kyoto University]], [[Hitotsubashi University]], [[University of Oxford]], [[Columbia University]], [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]], [[University of London]], [[Harvard University]], and many more. ==Accreditation== Accreditation actions had been taken at the [[American Academy for Liberal Education]] Board of Trustees Meeting at November 2005.{{cite web |url=http://www.aale.org/highered/decisions.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-07-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120511011141/http://aale.org/highered/decisions.html |archivedate=May 11, 2012 |df=mdy-all }} * International Christian University, Tokyo, Japan - granted Programmatic Accreditation, through November 2015 ICU's academic programs of the College of Liberal Arts and the Graduate School are individually chartered by the [[Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology|Japanese Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology]] (MEXT). ICU has also received accreditation from the Japan University Accreditation Association (JUAA).https://www.icu.ac.jp/en/about/info/evaluation.html ==Academic rankings== {{Infobox Japanese university ranking | TSU_N = | Kawai_N = | TR_N = | WE_N = 24 | ARWU_N = | ENSMP_N = | NikkeiBP_G = 10 | NikkeiBP_H = | NikkeiBP_K = | NikkeiBP_C = | NikkeiBP_KOY = | GBUDU_N = Most Selective (SA) | LINE_1 = 0 | QS_A = 174 | ARWU_A = | LINE_2 = | THE_W = | QS_W = | ARWU_W = | TR_W = | ENSMP_W = | NOTE_1 = | NOTE_2 = |THE_N=15}} There are several rankings related to ICU, shown below. ===General rankings=== In 2017, ICU was ranked 15th among all universities, and 3rd among private universities in Japan by Times Higher Education and Benesse.{{Cite news|url=https://www.timeshighereducation.com/rankings/japan-university/2017#!/page/0/length/25/sort_by/rank/sort_order/asc/cols/stats|title=Japan University Rankings 2017|date=2017-03-23|work=Times Higher Education (THE)|access-date=2017-04-04|language=en}} [[QS World University Rankings]] ranked ICU as 174th in Asia in 2016.{{Cite web|url=https://www.topuniversities.com/university-rankings/asian-university-rankings/2016|title=QS Asia rankings|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}} Forbes made a list of top 10 liberal arts colleges in Asia including ICU that was based on the 2014 QS University rankings for Asia.{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/pictures/gkle45i/top-10-liberal-arts-coll/#15d609e16742|title=Top 10 Liberal Arts Colleges In Asia - pg.1|last=Klebnikov|first=Sergei|website=Forbes|access-date=2017-04-04}} ===Alumni rankings=== According to the ''Weekly Economist'''s ({{Interlanguage link multi|Shūkan ekonomisuto|ja|3=エコノミスト (雑誌)}}) 2010 rankings and the ({{Interlanguage link multi|PRESIDENT inc.|ja|3=プレジデント社}}) article on 2006/10/16, graduates from ICU have the 24th best employment rate in 400 major companies, and their average graduate salary is the 4th best in Japan.{{cite web|url=http://www2.ttcn.ne.jp/honkawa/3865.html|title=Employment rate in 400 major companies rankings |year=2011 |publisher=Weekly Economist |accessdate=Apr 29, 2011|language=Japanese}}{{cite web|author=大学偏差値情報局 |time= 02:51|url=http://hensachi-ranking.seesaa.net/article/26733115.html#more |title=年収偏差値・給料偏差値ランキング（2006・10・16）：稼げる大学はどれ？ |publisher=Hensachi-ranking.seesaa.net |date=1999-02-22 |accessdate=2011-10-29}}This 400 major companies exclude foreign companies, thus the ranking position tends to be lower for ICU which has many alumni who work in foreign companies ===Popularity and selectivity=== ICU is one of the most selective universities in Japan. Its entrance difficulty is usually considered as one of the top among 730 private universities. National and public universities use different kinds of exams. Thus it's only comparable between universities in the same category, e.g., {{Interlanguage link multi|Yoyogi seminar|ja|3=代々木ゼミナール}} published Hensachi (the indication showing the entrance difficulties by prep schools) rankings.{{cite web|url=http://www.yozemi.ac.jp/rank/gakubu/index.html |title=代々木ゼミナール（予備校） - ご案内 |publisher= |accessdate=July 29, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110422110816/http://yozemi.ac.jp/rank/gakubu/index.html |archivedate=April 22, 2011 |df=mdy-all }} Japanese journalist {{Interlanguage link multi|Kiyoshi Shimano|ja|3=島野清志}} ranks its entrance difficulty as SA (most selective/out of 11 scales) in Japan, which includes only four private universities and 11 national universities.{{cite web |script-title=ja:危ない大学・消える大学 2012年版 |year=2011 |publisher=YELL books |url=https://www.amazon.co.jp/%E5%8D%B1%E3%81%AA%E3%81%84%E5%A4%A7%E5%AD%A6%E3%83%BB%E6%B6%88%E3%81%88%E3%82%8B%E5%A4%A7%E5%AD%A6-%EF%BC%92%EF%BC%90%EF%BC%91%EF%BC%92%E5%B9%B4%E7%89%88-YELL-books-%E5%B3%B6%E9%87%8E-%E6%B8%85%E5%BF%97/dp/4753930181|language=Japanese}} ==Notable Graduates== *[[Kei Akagi]] – jazz pianist *[[Princess Mako of Akishino]] (class of 2014) – member of the [[Imperial House of Japan|Japanese imperial family]]; she is the first-born granddaughter of the reigning [[Emperor of Japan|Emperor]] [[Akihito]] and [[Empress of Japan|Empress]] [[Empress Michiko|Michiko]]. *[[Princess Kako of Akishino]] (class of 2019) – member of the [[Imperial House of Japan|Japanese imperial family]]; she is the younger sister of Princess Mako. *[[Takeshi Amemiya]] – The Edward Ames Edmonds Professor of Economics at [[Stanford University]] *[[Toshio Arima]] – president of [[Fuji Xerox]] *[[Betsy Boze]] (née: Vogel) – CEO and dean of [[Kent State University Stark]] *[[Albert Chan (professor)|Albert Chan]] (1975) – president of [[Hong Kong Baptist University]]{{cite news|url=http://www.chinareviewnews.com/doc/1011/0/9/1/101109149.html?coluid=7&kindid=0&docid=101109149|title=陳新滋獲委任為香港浸會大學校長 (Chan Sun-Chi appointed as Hong Kong Baptist University president)|work=China Review News|date=2009-10-19|accessdate=2013-04-09}} *[[Kazuo Hirai]] – Chairman of [[Sony Corporation]] *[[Cosei Kawa]] – illustrator of children's books *[[Hiroaki Kitano]] – president and CEO of Sony Computer Science Laboratories, Inc, Professor of [[Okinawa Institute of Science and Technology]] *[[Shigeru Miyagawa]] – professor of Linguistics & Kochi-Manjiro professor of Japanese Language and Culture at [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] *[[Yoko Narahashi]] - prominent film producer and casting director *[[Mariko Peters]] – former Dutch politician and civil servant *[[Jay Rockefeller]] – U.S. senator from [[West Virginia]] *[[Hirotaka Takeuchi]] – professor at [[Harvard Business School]] and former dean of the [[Graduate School of International Corporate Strategy]] at [[Hitotsubashi University]] *[[Kazuko Yokoo]] – justice of the [[Supreme Court of Japan]] *[[Lydia Yu-Jose]] – Japanologist and professor at the [[Ateneo de Manila University]] *[[Nozomi Watanabe]] – [[ice dancer]] who regularly dances with [[Akiyuki Kido]]. They are the three-time Japanese national champions and placed 15th at the Torino Olympics. *[[Toyohiro Akiyama]] – TV journalist and first Japanese national to have flown in space ==Faculty== *[[Iwao Ayusawa]], joined staff in 1952. ==See also== {{Portal|Tokyo}} *[[International Christian University High School]] == References == {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{commons category}} *{{Official website|http://www.icu.ac.jp/ }} {{ja icon}} *[http://www.icu.ac.jp/en/ ICU website] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090605154357/http://science.icu.ac.jp/ ICU Science Faculty website] ([[bilingual]]) *[http://subsite.icu.ac.jp/ssri ICU Social Science Research Institute] (bilingual) *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100416140921/http://subsite.icu.ac.jp/elp/aboutELP.html English for Liberal Arts program website] *[http://www.jicuf.org/ Japan ICU Foundation] *[http://www.icu-h.ed.jp/ ICU High School website] {{ja icon}} {{Mitaka, Tokyo}} {{EU Institute in_Japan}} {{Association of Christian Universities and Colleges in Asia}} {{Super Global University}} {{Kantoh Collegiate American Football Association navbox}} {{Alliance of Asian Liberal Arts Universities}} {{Global Liberal Arts Alliance}} {{coord|35|41|15|N|139|31|46|E|region:JP-13_type:edu|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:International Christian University}} [[Category:International Christian University| ]] [[Category:Nondenominational Christian universities and colleges]] [[Category:Liberal arts colleges]] [[Category:Christianity in Japan]] [[Category:Private universities and colleges in Japan]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1949]] [[Category:Universities and colleges in Tokyo]] [[Category:Association of Christian Universities and Colleges in Asia]] [[Category:1949 establishments in Japan]] [[Category:Mitaka, Tokyo]]

'''KeyRaider''' is computer [[malware]] that affects jailbroken [[Apple_Inc.|Apple]] [[iOS]] devices, specifically [[iPhone|iPhones]], and allows criminals to steal users' login and password information, as well as to lock the devices and demand a ransom to unlock them. It was discovered by researchers from [[Palo Alto Networks]] and WeiPhone in August 2015, and is believed to have led to more than 225,000 people having their login and password information being stolen, making it, according to cybersecurity columnist, Joseph Steinberg, "one of the most damaging pieces of malware ever discovered in the Apple universe."<ref name ="steinberg">{{cite news| url=http://www.inc.com/joseph-steinberg/massive-iphone-user-data-breach-what-you-need-to-know.html |work=Inc. | title=Massive iPhone User Data Breach: What You Need to Know | date=August 31, 2015 | accessdate=September 2, 2015 |author=Joseph Steinberg |authorlink=Joseph Steinberg}}</ref> The malware was originally found on a Chinese website,<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-34114487 |work=BBC | title=Chinese iPhone users hit by 'KeyRaider' malware | date=September 1, 2015 | accessdate=September 2, 2015}}</ref> but has spread to 18 countries including the United States.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://money.cnn.com/2015/09/01/technology/apple-iphone-account-hack/ |work=CNN | title=More than 225,000 Apple iPhone Account Hacked | date=September 1, 2015 | accessdate=September 2, 2015 |author=David Goldman}}</ref> KeyRaider affects only iPhones that have been [[iOS jailbreaking|jailbroken]].<ref name="steinberg" />

{{Infobox scientist | name = Michael Persinger | image = Michael Persinger.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = Persinger in 2010 | birth_date = {{birth date|1945|06|26}} | birth_place = [[Jacksonville, Florida]], U.S. | death_date = {{death date and age|2018|8|14|1945|6|26}} | death_place= [[Sudbury, Ontario]], Canada | citizenship = Canadian
American | nationality = [[Canadians|Canadian]] | fields = [[Neurotheology]], [[Neuroscience]], [[Parapsychology]], [[Biophysics]], [[Geophysics]], [[Epilepsy]] | workplaces = [[Laurentian University]] | alma_mater = [[University of Wisconsin]]
[[University of Tennessee]]
[[University of Manitoba]] | known_for = Director of Laurentian University's Consciousness Research Laboratory. Notable for his work in the field of [[neurotheology]]. | awards = LIFT (Leader in Faculty Teaching), 2007
TVO (Ontario) Best Lecturer 2007
Laurentian University Research Excellence Award 1989
Sudbury Regional Brain Injury Association Lifetime Membership Award 2001 }} '''Michael A. Persinger''' (June 26, 1945 – August 14, 2018) was an American-Canadian [[professor]] of psychology at [[Laurentian University]], a position he had held from 1971 until his death in 2018. His most well-known hypotheses include the temporal lobes as the central correlate for [[Mysticism|mystical]] experiences, subtle changes in [[geomagnetic]] activity as mediators of [[Parapsychology|parapsychological]] phenomena, the tectonic strain within the Earth's crust as the source of [[Ball lightning|luminous phenomena]] attributed to [[Unidentified flying object|unidentified aerial objects]], and the importance of specific quantifications for energy (10−20 Joules), photon flux density (picoWatt per meter squared), and small shifts in magnetic field intensities (picoTesla to nanoTesla range) for integrating cellular activity as well as human [[thought]] with universal phenomena.{{Cite book|title=Neuropsychological bases of God beliefs|last=Persinger|first=Michael A.|publisher=Prager Publishers|year=1987|isbn=978-0275926489|location=New York|pages=}}{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael A.|date=Fall 2001|title=The Neuropsychiatry of Paranormal Experiences|url=https://pdfs.semanticscholar.org/4857/87022759ddf1dca6c2411937a3f9889115e2.pdf|journal=Neuropsychiatric Practice and Opinion|volume=13:4|pages=515–524|via=}}{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael A.|date=1983|title=Religious and Mystical Experiences as Artifacts of Temporal Lobe Function: A General Hypothesis|journal=Perceptual and Motor Skills|volume=57|issue=3_suppl|pages=1255–1262|doi=10.2466/pms.1983.57.3f.1255|pmid=6664802}}{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael A.|date=Summer 2010|title=10-20 Joules as a Neuromolecular Quantum in Medicinal Chemistry: An Alternative Approach to Myriad Molecular Pathways?|url=http://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/ben/cmc/2010/00000017/00000027/art00009|journal=Current Medicinal Chemistry|volume=17|issue=27|pages=3094–3098|doi=10.2174/092986710791959701|via=}}{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael A.|date=2015|title=Inverse relationship between photon flux densities and nanotesla magnetic fields over cell aggregates: Quantitative evidence for energetic conservation|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2211546315000455|journal=FEBS Open Bio|volume=5|pages=413–418|doi=10.1016/j.fob.2015.04.015|pmid=26005634|pmc=4436372|via=}}{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael|date=December 2008|title=Quantitative discrepancy in cerebral hemispheric temperature associated with "two consciousnesses" is predicted by neuroquantum relations|url=|journal=NeuroQuantology|volume=6|pages=369–378|via=}}{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael|date=2007|title=A theory of neurophysics ad quantum neuroscience: implications for brain function and the limits of consciousness|url=|journal=Intern. J. Neuroscience|volume=117|pages=117–157|via=}}{{Cite journal|last=Dotta|first=Blake|date=2011|title=Photon emissions from human brain and cell culture exposed to distally rotating magnetic fields shared by separate light-stimulated brains and cells|url=|journal=Brain Research|volume=|pages=77–88|via=}}{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael|date=2008|title=A Neuroquantologic approach to how human thought might affect the Universe|url=|journal=NeuroQuantology|volume=6|pages=262–271|via=}} Persinger's experimental work on paranormal experiences has received widespread media coverage but has also been widely criticised. His major research themes have included [[electromagnetic field]] effects upon biological organisms, [[epilepsy]], [[temporal lobe]] functions, properties of [[biophoton]]s, [[Geophysics|geophysical]]-human interactions, [[physical cosmology]], and the quantifiable examination of what Persinger terms "low-probability phenomena" such as [[time travel]], [[Parallel Universes (nonfiction)|parallel universes]], and the [[Simulation hypothesis|universe as a simulation]].{{Cite book|title=Space-time transients and unusual events|last=Persinger|first=Michael A.|publisher=Nelson-Hall|year=1977|isbn=978-0-88229-334-9|location=Chicago|pages=231}} He has published over 500 technical [[Academic article|articles]] in scientific journals, more than a dozen chapters in various books, and seven of his own books.{{Cite web|url=https://neurocogconsultants.app.box.com/s/onl9c9zjvyi2w9uk3oz4bfmhq03t17q5|title=Persinger CV|last=|first=|date=|website=neurocogconsultants.app.box.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-06-17}} His book with Ghislaine Lafreniere, entitled ''Space-Time Transients and Unusual Events'' (1977), documents the search for patterns in phenomena that are not compatible with current [[scientific paradigm]]s.{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael|date=June 2016|title=Translocations In Space-Time and Simultaneous States of the Universe:Convergent Quantifications and Alternative Solutions from the Principles of Physics for the Challenges of "Time Travel" and "Parallel Universes"|url=|journal=Journal of Advances in Physics|volume=11|pages=2347–3487|via=}}{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael|date=July 2016|title=Quantitative Conditions and Convergent Operations That Are Compatible With the Universe as a Persistent Generator of Successive Simulations|url=|journal=Journal of Advances in Physics|volume=12|pages=2347–3487|via=}} He argued that all phenomena including [[consciousness]], [[spiritual experiences]], and "[[paranormal]] events" can be explained by universal physical mechanisms and can be verified using [[Scientific method|the scientific method]].{{Citation|last=Nik TheSaint|title=Michael Persinger - Psychotropic drugs and nature of reality|date=2012-12-09|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1b6-Pe278HA|accessdate=2017-06-18}} He contended quantitative differences in [[energy]], rather than qualitative distinctions, are responsible for the apparent mind-body duality.{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael A.|date=2015|title=The physical bases to consciousness: Implications of convergent quantifications|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/307787426|journal=Journal of Systems and Integrative Neuroscience|volume=1|issue=2|pages=55–64|via=|doi=10.15761/jsin.1000111}} Further, he has claimed that the structure and function of the [[brain]] determine the boundaries of human perception of the [[universe]], and that shared quantitative values connect local phenomena with fundamental properties of the cosmos - expanding upon the work of [[Arthur Eddington|Sir Arthur Eddington]].{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael A.|date=1999|title=On the nature of space-time in the observation of physical events in science|url=http://www.nrgarchive.gdk.mx/1999-Persinger-PMS-On-the-nature-of-space-time-in-the-observation-of-physical-events-in-science.pdf?i=1|journal=Perceptual and Motor Skills|volume=88|issue=3_suppl|pages=1210–1216|via=|doi=10.2466/pms.1999.88.3c.1210|pmid=10485103}}{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael A.|date=2013|title=Support for Eddington's Number and his Approach to Astronomy: Recent Developments in the Physics and Chemistry of the Human Brain|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/277934216|journal=International Letters of Chemistry, Physics, and Astronomy|volume=13|pages=8–19|via=|doi=10.18052/www.scipress.com/ilcpa.13.8}} ==Early life== Persinger attended [[Carroll College (Wisconsin)|Carroll College]] from 1963 to 1964 and graduated from the [[University of Wisconsin–Madison]] in 1967. He received his [[Master of Arts|M.A.]] in [[physiological psychology]] from the [[University of Tennessee]] in 1969 and his [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] from the [[University of Manitoba]] in 1971. ==Research and academic work== Persinger's work focuses on the commonalities that exist between the sciences, and aims to integrate fundamental concepts of various branches of science.{{cite journal |last = Persinger |first1 = M. A.|year = 1999 |title = On the nature of space-time in the observation of physical events in science|journal = Perceptual and Motor Skills|pages = 1210–1216|volume = 88 |issue = 3_suppl|doi=10.2466/pms.1999.88.3c.1210|pmid = 10485103}} He organized the [[Behavioural neuroscience|Behavioral Neuroscience]] Program at [[Laurentian University]] in Sudbury, Ontario, integrating [[chemistry]], [[biology]], and [[psychology]]. Persinger has published hundreds of peer-reviewed academic journal articles, contributing to several fields of study. === Clinical and experimental neuropsychology === {{main|God helmet}}Most of Persinger's published articles involved with consciousness have focused on the persistence of experiences reported by individuals who display [[Complex partial seizure|complex partial epilepsy]] within the normal population of people who are [[Creativity|creative]], subject to frequent paranormal experiences, or who have sustained a [[Mild head injury|mild impact of mechanical energy to the cerebrum]].{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael|date=1987|title=Temporal lobe epileptic signs and correlative behaviors displayed by normal populations|url=|journal=The Journal of General Psychology|volume=114|pages=179–195|via=}}{{Cite journal|last=Baker-Price|first=Laura|date=2003|title=Intermittent burst-firing weak (1 microtesla) magnetic fields reduce psychometric depression in patients who sustained closed head injuries: a replication and electroencephalographic validation|url=|journal=Perceptual and Motor Skills|volume=96|pages=965–974|via=}}{{Cite journal|last=Corradini|first=Paula|date=2014|title=Spectral power, source localization and microstates to quantify chronic deficits from "mild" closed head injury: Correlation with classic neuropsychological tests|url=|journal=Brain Injury|volume=|pages=1–11|via=}} One of his notable experiments, spanning about three decades, involved a helmet ("the [[God helmet|God Helmet]]"), whereby weak physiologically-patterned magnetic fields were applied across the temporal lobes of hundreds of volunteers. The research received wide media coverage{{Cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/books/10914137/What-God-does-to-your-brain.html|title=What God does to your brain|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}{{Cite web|url=http://news.nationalpost.com/holy-post/what-god-does-to-your-brain-controversial-science-of-neurotheology-aims-to-find-out-why-people-have-faith|title=What god does to your brain: Controversial science of neurotheology aims to find out why people have faith|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.wired.com/1999/11/persinger/|title=This is your brain on god|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}} with high-profile visitors to Persinger's laboratory including [[Susan Blackmore]] and [[Richard Dawkins]] reporting positive{{cite journal|url=https://www.nature.com/news/2004/041206/full/news041206-10.html |title=Electrical brainstorms busted as source of ghosts| publisher=Nature |date=2004-12-09 |author=Roxanne Khamsi }} and negative[http://www.bbc.co.uk/science/horizon/2003/godonbrain.shtml BBC Article] results respectively. Experiences often associated with mystical reports such as [[Out-of-body experience|out-of-body-experiences]], [[Intrusive thought|intrusive thoughts,]] and the [[Sense of presence|sensed presence]] were reported by hundreds of volunteers over decades of studying the phenomenon, which were not associated with the subjects’ [[suggestibility]].{{Cite journal|last=St.- Pierre|first=Linda S.|date=2009|title=Experimental facilitation of the sensed presence is predicted by the specific patterns of the applied magnetic fields, not by suggestibility: re-analyses of 19 experiments|journal=International Journal of Neuroscience|volume=116|issue=9|pages=1079–1096|doi=10.1080/00207450600808800|pmid=16861170}}{{Cite journal|last=Tinoco|first=Carlos A.|date=2014|title=Magnetic Stimulation of the Temporal Cortex: A Partial "God Helmet" Replication Study|url=http://jcer.com/index.php/jcj/article/viewFile/361/386|journal=Journal of Consciousness Exploration & Research|volume=5|pages=234–257|via=}}{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael|date=2003|title=The sensed presence within experimental settings: implications for the male and female concept of self|url=|journal=The Journal of Psychology|volume=137|issue=1|pages=5–16|via=|pmid=12661700|doi=10.1080/00223980309600595}}{{Cite journal|last=Booth|first=Nicholas|date=2009|title=Discrete Shifts Within the Theta Band Between the Frontal and Parietal Regions of the Right Hemisphere and the Experiences of a Sensed Presence|url=|journal=Journal of Neuropsychiatry and Clinical Neuroscience|volume=21|pages=279–283|via=}} Subsequent theory and [[Quantitative electroencephalography|quantitative electroencephalographic]] measurements supported the contention that the sensed presence of a "sentient being" could be a normal brain-based prototype for god experiences or related mystical phenomena and was actually the [[Left hemisphere|left hemispheric]] awareness of the [[Right hemisphere|right hemispheric]] equivalent to the left hemispheric [[sense of self]].{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael A.|date=2002|title=EXPERIMENTAL FACILITATION OF THE SENSED PRESENCE: POSSIBLE INTERCALATION BETWEEN THE HEMISPHERES INDUCED BY COMPLEX MAGNETIC FIELDS|url=http://journals.lww.com/jonmd/Abstract/2002/08000/Experimental_Facilitation_of_the_Sensed_Presence_.6.aspx|journal=The Journal of Nervous and Mental Disease|volume=190|issue=8|pages=533–541|via=|doi=10.1097/00005053-200208000-00006}} Similar experiences were reported by people who had applied Todd Murphy's technology.{{Cite journal|last=Tsang|first=E.W.|date=2009|title=ELECTROPHYSIOLOGICAL AND QUANTITATIVE ELECTROENCEPHALOGRAPHIC MEASUREMENTS AFTER TREATMENT BY TRANSCEREBRAL MAGNETIC FIELDS GENERATED BY COMPACT DISC THROUGH A COMPUTER SOUND CARD: THE SHAKTI TREATMENT|journal=International Journal of Neuroscience|volume=114|issue=8|pages=1013–1024|doi=10.1080/00207450490461323}} However, other researchers either did not [[Replication (statistics)|replicate]] or only partially replicated the experimental effects with variations of the helmet.{{Cite journal|last=Andersen|first=M.|date=2014|title=Mystical Experience in the Lab|journal=Method & Theory in the Study of Religion|volume=26|issue=3|pages=217–245|doi=10.1163/15700682-12341323}}{{Cite journal|last=Granqvist|first=P.|date=2005|title=Sensed presence and mystical experiences are predicted by suggestibility, not by the application of transcranial weak complex magnetic fields|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0304394004013473|journal=Neuroscience Letters|volume=379|issue=1|pages=1–6|via=|doi=10.1016/j.neulet.2004.10.057|pmid=15849873}}{{Cite journal|last=Larsson|first=M.|date=2005|title=Reply to MA Persinger and SA Koren's response to Granqvist et al."Sensed presence and mystical experiences are predicted by suggestibility, not by the application of transcranial weak magnetic fields|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/247090565|journal=Neuroscience Letters|volume=380|issue=3|pages=348–350|via=|doi=10.1016/j.neulet.2005.03.059}} In 2014, Tinoco and colleagues reported an independent replication of an experimental protocol which measured verbal behavior associated with field exposures using the helmet configuration.{{Cite journal|last=Richards|first=Pauline M.|date=1993|title=Modification of activation and evaluation properties of narratives by weak complex magnetic field patterns that simulate limbic burst firing|journal=International Journal of Neuroscience|volume=71|pages=71–85|doi=10.3109/00207459309000594}} In an earlier study by Richards and colleagues, semantic memory was similarly affected by applications of weak magnetic fields over the temporal lobes.{{Cite journal|last=Richards|first=Pauline|date=July Alternative models, developed by Persinger and David Vares, were quantified for interaction between quantum values and specific magnitude earthquakes, [[Climate change|global climate variations]], interactions with [[Population density|population densities]], discrete energies as mediators of disease, and processes by which human cognition could be covertly affected by [[Schumann resonances|Schumann Resonances]] and geomagnetic activity.{{Cite journal|last=Vares|first=David|date=2015|title=Correlations between US county annual cancer incidence and population density|url=|journal=American Journal of Cancer Research|volume=5|pages=3467–3474|via=}}{{Cite journal|last=Vares|first=David|date=2016|title=Quantification of the diminishing earth['s magnetic dipole intensity and geomagnetic activity as the causal source for global warming within the oceans and atmosphere|url=|journal=International Journal of Geosciences|volume=7|pages=78–90|via=}} The hypothesis was recently criticized by a prominent blogger.{{cite web|url=http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/neuroskeptic/2015/10/16/magnetism-neuroscience-to-climate-change/|title=Magnetism: From Neuroscience to Climate Change?|author=Neuroskeptic}} Persinger has estimated that the total biomass of the planet was equivalent to the accumulated solar energy (solar constant) on the Earth's surface. The shared photon origin was considered one source for "[[Entanglement (physics)|entanglement]]" between living systems.{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael A.|date=2016|title=The Biomass of the Earth as the Direct Energy-Mass Equivalence from ~3.5 Billions of Years of Solar Flux|url=https://www.infona.pl/resource/bwmeta1.element.psjd-eee6525a-f4df-4d8e-bf94-fcf39f938dc2|journal=World Scientific News|volume=|pages=|via=}} === Parapsychological research === Persinger has stated that he studies parapsychological phenomena because "the ultimate subject matter of science is the unknown". He believes that verifiable spontaneous and experimental types of parapsychological phenomena are physical and associated with non-local interactions between human brain activity and geophysical processes. For example, Persinger has presented evidence that the moderate strength correlation between geomagnetic activity at the time of a [[Precognition|precognitive]] experience and what the geomagnetic activity would be two to three days before the event was considered supportive evidence that energetic antecedents before the event, not the event itself, was being discerned.{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael A.|date=1988|title=Increased geomagnetic activity and the occurrence of bereavement hallucinations: Evidence for melatonin-mediated microseizuring in the temporal lobe?|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0304394088902224|journal=Neuroscience Letters|volume=88|issue=3|pages=271–274|via=|doi=10.1016/0304-3940(88)90222-4}} Review of the physical properties with [[William G. Roll|W. G. Roll]] of verified [[poltergeist]] phenomena indicated the prevalence of physical properties coupled to increases in geomagnetic activity due to minute changes in the Earth's rotational [[Angular momentum|(angular) momentum]].{{Cite journal|last=Roll|first=William G.|date=1998|title=Poltergeist and Nonlocality: Energetic Aspects of RSPK|url=http://search.proquest.com/openview/4e30217b27a7978a9194dc4d0231eb46/1?pq-origsite=gscholar&cbl=1818062|journal=The Journal of Parapsychology|volume=|pages=|via=}} During the 1980s, Persinger showed that both experimental and spontaneous cases of "[[telepathy]] and [[clairvoyance]] ("[[remote viewing]]") were more likely when the global geomagnetic activity was lower than the days before or afterwards.{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael A.|date=1985|title=Geophysical Variables and Behavior: XXX. Intense Paranormal Experiences Occur during Days of Quiet, Global, Geomagnetic Activity|journal=Perceptual and Motor Skills|volume=61|pages=320–322|doi=10.2466/pms.1985.61.1.320}} Measurement of the activity associated with Sean Harribance|url=http://www.ijoy.org.in/article.asp?issn=0973-6131;year=2012;volume=5;issue=2;spage=140;epage=145;aulast=Persinger|journal=International Journal of from the right cerebral hemisphere, and small decreases in the intensity of the geomagnetic field when the details of their experiences were most accurate. === Physical cosmology === Later in his career, Persinger and his lifelong colleague Stanley Koren quantitatively, through calculations, explored the non-traditional relationships between the smallest and largest increments of space and time.{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael A.|date=2014|title=Evidence for a Causal Relationship Between Mach's Principle and the Quantitative Latency for Universal Entanglement|url=http://yadda.icm.edu.pl/yadda/element/bwmeta1.element.baztech-7e1025e3-3f45-4f2f-a208-b189a89da574|journal=International Letters of Chemistry, Physics and Astronomy|volume=|pages=|via=}}{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael|date=May 2016|title=Inflections of periodicities of background photon spectral power densities are predicted by the lorentz contraction for a potential indicator for the intrinsic structure of space|url=|journal=Journal of Advances in Physics|volume=|pages=4014–4017|via=}} For example, the time required for the universe to expand one [[Planck length|Planck's length]] was [[Planck time|Planck's time]], and the time for Planck's length to expand one Planck's length was [[Age of the universe|the age of the universe]].{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael A.|date=2007|title=A THEORY OF NEUROPHYSICS AND QUANTUM NEUROSCIENCE: IMPLICATIONS FOR BRAIN FUNCTION AND THE LIMITS OF CONSCIOUSNESS|journal=International Journal of Neuroscience|volume=117|issue=2|pages=157–175|doi=10.1080/00207450500535784|pmid=17365106}} This duration for a [[proton]] was about 3 ms, which considered the optimal point duration for interactive magnetic fields. [[Dark matter]] and [[Dark energy|energy]] were considered [[matter]] and [[energy]] yet to occur before the [[Ultimate fate of the universe|final epoch]]. Persinger has authored several publications in physical cosmology relating [[gravity]] and [[light]] to universal constants.{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael A.|date=2012|title=Potential Origins of a Quantitative Equivalence Between Gravity and Light|url=https://benthamopen.com/contents/pdf/TOAAJ/TOAAJ-5-41.pdf|journal=The Open Astronomy Journal|volume=|pages=|via=}} Three different approaches solved for a velocity associated with entanglement of 1023 [[Metre per second|meters per second]], which predicted that excess correlation could show a discrete latency.{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael A.|date=2015|title=Entanglement Velocity of 10^ sup 23^ m* s^ sup-1^ To Accommodate Recent Measurements of Large Scale Structures of the Universe.|url=|journal=International Letters of Chemistry, Physics and Astronomy|volume=|pages=|via=}} Because the product of this velocity, [[Speed of light|the speed of light]], and the upper boundary for the rest mass of a photon{{Cite journal|last=Tu|first=Liang-Cheng|date=2005|title=The mass of the photon|journal=Reports on Progress in Physics|volume=68|pages=77–130|doi=10.1088/0034-4885/68/1/R02}} resulted in 10−20 J, Persinger has hypothesized that photons could have both local and non-local effects.{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael A.|date=2016|title=Hidden Connections Between NanoTesla Magnetic Fields, Cosic Molecular Resonance, and Photonic Fields Within Living Systems|url=https://www.infona.pl/resource/bwmeta1.element.psjd-e3b1d38e-0ff8-4f62-894b-50daa6482b02|journal=World Scientific News|volume=|pages=|via=}} == Free speech == In 2016, Persinger was controversially removed as the instructor of a first-year psychology course.{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/sudbury/persinger-psychology-class-1.3389410|title=Free speech or foul play? Longtime prof removed for offensive language policy|work=CBC News|access-date=2017-06-17|language=en}} The [[Provost (education)|provost]] at Laurentian said they objected to his asking students to sign a ''statement of understanding'' that vulgar language might be used in the class. The Laurentian University Faculty Association filed a [[grievance]] against the school for violating Persinger's [[academic freedom]]. Current and former students also protested the decision.{{Cite web|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2016/01/06/students-rally-in-defence-of-controversial-laurentian-university-professor.html|title=Students rally in defence of controversial Laurentian University professor|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}
"One of my techniques is to expose people to all types of different words [...] silly words, complex words, emotional words, profane words. Because they influence how you make decisions and how you think."{{Cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/sudbury/persinger-psychology-class-1.3389410|title=Laurentian University professor removed for asking students to agree to profane language|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}- CBC News, January 4, 2016

[[Annapolis Group]] |website = {{url|www.millsaps.edu}} |logo = [[File:Millsaps College.png|200px]] }} '''Millsaps College''' is a private [[Liberal arts colleges in the United States|liberal arts college]] located in [[Jackson, Mississippi]], the state capital. Founded in 1890 and affiliated with the [[United Methodist Church]], Millsaps is home to 985 students. One of 40 colleges featured in Loren Pope's ''Colleges That Change Lives,'' it is one of only 21 private colleges nationwide named a ''Best Buy'' in the 2013 ''Fiske Guide to Colleges''. ==History== The college was founded in 1889–90 by a [[Confederate States of America|Confederate]] veteran, Major [[Reuben Webster Millsaps]], who donated the land for the college and $50,000. Dr. [[William Belton Murrah]] was the college's first president, and Bishop [[Charles Betts Galloway]] of the [[Methodist Episcopal Church South]] organized the college's early fund-raising efforts. Both men were honored with halls named in their honor. Major Millsaps and his wife are interred in a tomb near the center of campus. The current United Methodist Church continues to have affiliations with the college. ===Important dates in Millsaps history=== [[File:Major Reuben Webster Millsaps grave.jpg|thumb|right|Mausoleum on the campus of Millsaps College, Jackson, Mississippi, containing the graves of Major Reuben Webster Millsaps and his wife.]] * 1890: Major Reuben Webster Millsaps founds the college with a personal gift of $50,000. * 1901: Millsaps builds the first [[golf]] course in Mississippi. * 1902: Mary Letitia Holloman becomes the first female graduate of Millsaps. * 1908: Sing-Ung Zung of [[Suzhou, Jiangsu|Soochow]], [[People's Republic of China|China]], becomes the first [[international]] student to graduate from Millsaps. * 1914: Old Main, one of the first buildings on campus, burns and is replaced by Murrah Hall. * 1916: Major Millsaps dies and is buried on campus. * 1931: The first night [[American football|football]] game in Mississippi is played on the Millsaps campus between the Majors and Mississippi A&M (now [[Mississippi State University]]). * 1936: Millsaps College absorbs bankrupt [[Grenada College]] during the [[Great Depression]]. * 1943: [[Johnny Carson]] attends Millsaps for [[V-12 Navy College Training Program|V-12]] naval officer training, entertaining his comrades with a magic and humor act. * 1944: [[Louis H. Wilson]], who graduated from the college in 1941, received the [[Medal of Honor]] for his actions at the [[Battle of Guam (1944)|Battle of Guam]] during [[World War II]]. Wilson became a [[General]] and the 26th [[Commandant of the Marine Corps]] in 1975. He was the first Marine Corps Commandant to serve full-time on the [[Joint Chiefs of Staff]]. * 1953: [[Dean Martin]] and [[Jerry Lewis]] judge a Millsaps beauty contest. * 1965: Millsaps becomes the first all-white college in Mississippi to voluntarily [[Desegregation|desegregate]].{{cite web |last=Millsaps College |title=Millsaps timeline |url=http://www.millsaps.edu/get_to_know/timeline/ |accessdate=2006-08-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060906224653/http://www.millsaps.edu/get_to_know/timeline/ |archivedate=2006-09-06 |df= }} * 1967: [[Robert Kennedy]] during his presidential campaign speaks at the college about obligations of young Americans to give back to their country. * 1975: President [[Jimmy Carter]] speaks to Millsaps students about the crisis in the [[Middle East]]. * 1988: Millsaps initiates the first campus chapter of [[Habitat for Humanity]] in Mississippi. * 1989: Millsaps becomes the first school in Mississippi to have a chapter of the [[Phi Beta Kappa]] honor society. ===Presidents=== * [[William Belton Murrah]], 1890–1910 * David Carlisle Hull, 1910–1912 * Dr. Alexander Farrar Watkins, 1912–1923 * Dr. [[David Martin Key]], 1923–1938 * Dr. Marion Lofton Smith, 1938–1952 * Dr. [[Homer Ellis Finger, Jr.]], 1952–1964 * Dr. Benjamin Barnes Graves, 1965–1970 * Dr. Edward McDaniel Collins, Jr., 1970–1978 *Dr. George Marion Harmon (1978–2000) - After 22 years of leading Millsaps College, Dr. Harmon announced his resignation in the Spring of 1999. His last day as president of Millsaps College was June 30, 2000.[http://www.millsaps.edu/news_events/flt/southern.shtml The Magnolia Gazette: Southern ties launch a new era for Millsaps] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080705154844/http://www.millsaps.edu/news_events/flt/southern.shtml |date=2008-07-05 }} *Dr. [[Frances Lucas]] (2000–2010) - Dr. Lucas was the first female to hold the post at Millsaps.[http://www.millsaps.edu/news_events/flt/april_ledger1.shtml The Clarion-Ledger: Millsaps installs 1st female leader] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060905050221/http://www.millsaps.edu/news_events/flt/april_ledger1.shtml |date=2006-09-05 }} Dr. Lucas resigned on April 23, 2009.[http://www.jacksonfreepress.com/index.php/site/comments/millsaps_president_announces_resignation_042309/ Jackson Free Press: Millsaps President Announces Resignation] Lucas cited disagreements with faculty as the reason for her resignation.[http://www.msbusiness.com/article.cfm?ID=8116 Mississippi Business Journal: Lucas leaving Millsaps] {{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} *Howard McMillan, Dean of Millsaps' Else School of Management took over as Interim President in August 2009.[http://www.clarionledger.com/article/20090722/NEWS/907220353/1001/news/Millsaps-dean-selected-to-take-on-presidential-duties-during-search The Clarion-Ledger: Millsaps dean selected to take on presidential duties during search] *Dr. Robert Pearigen, Vice President of University Relations at [[The University of the South]], was selected to serve as the eleventh president of the college. He began his term in office on July 1, 2010.[http://www.millsaps.edu/about_millsaps/about_president_dr_robert_pearigen.php Robert Pearigen] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100510001120/http://www.millsaps.edu/about_millsaps/about_president_dr_robert_pearigen.php |date=2010-05-10 }} ==Academics== Despite its religious affiliation, the curriculum is secular. The writing-intensive core curriculum requires each student to compile an acceptable portfolio of written work before completion of the sophomore year. Candidates for an undergraduate degree must also pass oral and written [[Comprehensive examination|comprehensive exams]] in their major field of study. These exams last up to three hours, and may cover any required or elective course offered by the major department. Unacceptable performance on comprehensive exams will prevent a candidate from receiving a degree, even if all course work has been completed. "Comps" are usually associated with graduate degree requirements, so their inclusion at the undergraduate level is a source of pride (and possibly pressure) for Millsaps students. {{Citation needed|date=February 2012}} Millsaps offers [[Bachelor of Science|B.S.]], [[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]], [[Bachelor of Business Administration|B.B.A.]], [[Master of Business Administration|M.B.A.]] and [[Master of Accountancy|MAcc]] degrees and corresponding programs. The current undergraduate population is 910 students on a 103 [[acre]] (417,000 m²) campus near downtown [[Jackson, Mississippi]]. The student to faculty ratio is 1:9 with an average class size around 15 students. Millsaps offers 32 majors and 41 minors, including the option of a self-designed major, along with a multitude of study abroad and internship opportunities. Millsaps employs 97 full-time faculty members. Of those, 94 percent of tenure-track faculty hold a Ph.D. or the terminal degree in their field. The professors on the [[tenure]] track have the highest degree in their field.{{Citation needed|date=February 2012}} The college offers research partnerships for undergraduate students, and a variety of study abroad programs. Millsaps reports that 57% of their student body comes from outside Mississippi; a large portion of out-of-state students are from neighboring [[Louisiana]]. Millsaps is home to 910 undergraduate, 75 graduate students from 26 states and territories plus 23 countries. The college also offers a [[Continuing Education]] program and the Community Enrichment Series for adults in the Jackson area. ==Campus== [[File:Millsaps College.jpg|thumb|left|Millsaps College campus.]] The Millsaps campus is close to downtown Jackson. It is bordered by Woodrow Wilson Avenue to the north, North State Street to the east, West Street to the west, and Marshall Street to the south. The center of campus is dominated by "The Bowl," where many events occur, including Homecoming activities, concerts, the Multicultural Festival, and Commencement. Adjacent to the Bowl is the Campbell College Center, renovated in 2000, which contains the campus bookstore, post office, cafeteria, and Student Life offices. This central section of campus also holds the Gertrude C. Ford Academic Complex, Olin Science Hall, Sullivan-Harrell Hall, and the Millsaps-Wilson Library. The north part of campus includes the Hall Activities Center (commonly called "the HAC"), the sports fields, and the freshman dormitories. On the far northwestern corner is James Observatory, the oldest building on campus. Operational since 1901, the observatory underwent major renovations in 1980. It is open for celestial gazing. Upperclassmen dormitories are located on the south side of campus, with Fraternity Row and the Christian Center. Originally constructed as a memorial to students and graduates who died in service during World War II, the Christian Center houses an auditorium and the departments of Performing Arts, History and Religious Studies. Between the Christian Center and Murrah Hall, which houses the Else School of Management, is the tomb of Major Millsaps and the "M" Bench, erected by the classes of 1926, 1927, and 1928. The Nicholson Garden was added to improve the aesthetics of this area. ==Rankings and distinctions== Millsaps was ranked 90 out of 251 national liberal arts colleges in the [[U.S. News & World Report]] of America's Best Colleges Issue; top ranked liberal arts college in Mississippi, Louisiana, and Alabama; also, named to the list of "High School Counselors' Picks" for 2011 and 2012.{{cite web|url=http://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-colleges/millsaps-college-2414 |title=Millsaps College | Best College | US News |publisher=Colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com |date= |accessdate=2014-08-20}} Millsaps College professors are ranked among the best in the nation, according to The [[Princeton Review]]'s The Best 377 Colleges - 2013 Edition. The Millsaps faculty won praise in The Princeton Review's special Top 20 category: Professors Get High Marks, where Millsaps was ranked twelfth in the country.{{cite web|url=http://www.princetonreview.com/college-rankings.aspx |title=College Rankings |publisher=Princetonreview.com |date= |accessdate=2014-08-20}} The [[Princeton Review]] also named the Else School of Management at Millsaps College one of the Best Business Schools in the Southeast in the 2011 edition of its book, ''The Best 300 Business Schools''.{{cite web|url=http://www.princetonreview.com/business-school-rankings.aspx |title=Business School Rankings |publisher=Princetonreview.com |date= |accessdate=2014-08-20}} Millsaps is one of 40 schools in [[Loren Pope]]'s ''[[Colleges That Change Lives]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.ctcl.org/ |title=Colleges That Change Lives | Changing Lives. One Student at a Time |publisher=Ctcl.org |date= |accessdate=2014-08-20}} Millsaps is among 21 private universities and colleges nationwide named a "best buy" in the ''[[Fiske Guide to Colleges]] 2013''. Millsaps is the only institution in Mississippi to earn the "best buy" honor from the annual guide. The guide names Millsaps as "the strongest liberal arts college in the deep, Deep South and by far the most progressive" and notes that what differentiates the school is "its focus on scholarly inquiry, spiritual growth, and community service, along with its Heritage Program, an interdisciplinary approach to world culture." Millsaps leads the list of 13 [[United Methodist]]–related colleges named among the top 100 liberal arts colleges by the 2012 [[Washington Monthly]] College Guide.{{cite web|url=http://www.washingtonmonthly.com/college_guide/rankings_2012/liberal_arts_rank.php |title=Liberal Arts College Rankings 2012 |publisher=Washington Monthly |date= |accessdate=2014-08-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130115154936/http://www.washingtonmonthly.com/college_guide/rankings_2012/liberal_arts_rank.php |archivedate=2013-01-15 |df= }} ==Athletics== {{main|Millsaps Majors}} The school's sports teams [[List of U.S. college team nicknames|are known as]] the Majors, and their colors are purple and white. They participate in the [[NCAA Division III]] and the [[Southern Athletic Association]]. Men's sports include: baseball, basketball, cheerleading, cross country, football, golf, lacrosse, soccer, tennis, and track and field,and the addition of a 2019-2020 swim team. Women's sports include basketball, cheerleading, cross country, dance team, golf, lacrosse, soccer, softball, tennis, track and field, and volleyball,and the addition of a 2019-2020 swim team. The Majors had a fierce football and basketball rivalry with [[Mississippi College]] in nearby [[Clinton, Mississippi|Clinton]] through the 1950s before competition was suspended after an infamous student brawl at a basketball game. Campus legend says the brawl was sparked by the alleged theft of the body of Millsaps founder Major Millsaps by Mississippi College students. The rivalry was considered by many as the best in Mississippi, featuring a prank by Mississippi College students who painted "TO HELL WITH MILSAPS" (sic) on the Millsaps Observatory. The football rivalry resumed in 2000 as the "Backyard Brawl", with games at [[Mississippi Veterans Memorial Stadium]]. The rivalry took a one-year hiatus in 2005 but resumed in 2006. Millsaps was the summer training camp home for the [[National Football League|NFL's]] [[New Orleans Saints]] in 2006, 2007, and 2008. Millsaps was also home to the famous game-ending play in the [[2007 Trinity vs. Millsaps football game]], in which [[Trinity University (Texas)|Trinity University]] executed 15 laterals on the way to a touchdown, defeating Millsaps by a score of 28-24. The play later won the Pontiac Game-Changing Performance of the Year award, which had never before been bestowed upon a play outside of the [[NCAA]]'s [[NCAA#Football Bowl Subdivision|Bowl Subdivision]]. In 2008, Millsaps quarterback [[Juan Joseph]] was awarded the [[Conerly Trophy]], which goes to the best football player in the state of [[Mississippi]]. ==Greek organizations== The school is home to five different [[fraternities and sororities|fraternities]]: [[Kappa Alpha Order]], [[Sigma Alpha Epsilon]], [[Pi Kappa Alpha]], [[Lambda Chi Alpha]], and [[Kappa Sigma]]; as well as five [[fraternities and sororities|sororities]]: [[Delta Delta Delta]], [[Kappa Delta]], [[Phi Mu]], [[Chi Omega]], and [[Alpha Kappa Alpha]]. ==Navy V-12 program== Nearly 53 years after founding the college, Millsaps was chosen as one of 131 sites for the training of [[United States Navy|Navy]] and [[U.S. Marines|Marine]] officers in the [[V-12 Navy College Training Program]]. In April 1943, 380 students arrived for the Navy V-12 program. It offered [[engineering]], pre-[[Medicine|medical]] and pre-[[Dentistry|dental]]. Thereafter Millsaps began accepting students year-round for the program. A total of 873 officer candidates went through Millsaps between 1943 and 1945. Traces of the Navy V-12 unit appear in the ''Bobashela'' (school [[yearbook]]) in 1944. That year, the ''Bobashela'' staff decided to dedicate the yearbook to the unit and Dr. Sanders, one of the unit's advisers. '''Mudsill theory''' is a sociological term indicating the proposition that there must be, and always has been, a [[Underclass|lower class]] for the [[upper classes]] to rest upon. The term derives from a [[mudsill]], the lowest threshold that supports the [[Foundation (architecture)|foundation]] for a building.
The theory was first used by South Carolina [[United States Senate|Senator]]/[[Governor of South Carolina|Governor]] [[James Henry Hammond]], a wealthy [[Plantation era|southern plantation]] owner, in a [[United States Senate|Senate]] speech on March 4, 1858,<ref>[https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/aia/part4/4h3439t.html Africans in America/Part 4/Mudsill Theory<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> to justify what he saw as the willingness of the [[lower classes]] and the duty of non-whites to perform menial work which enabled the [[upper classes|higher classes]] to move civilization forward. Efforts to reduce [[Social class|class]] or [[racial inequality]], under this theory, inevitably run counter to civilization itself.
Many saw the argument as a weak justification for [[Exploitation of labour|exploitation]], and a flimsy example of creating your own [[science]] to reference as [[Logical argument|proof]].<ref>[[Richard Hofstadter|Hofstadter, Richard]]. The American Political Tradition & the Men Who Made It. New York, NY: Knopf, 1974. 86-117.</ref> An obvious flaw lies in that there are no indications as to which class or race rightfully belongs to the mudsill other than the pre-supposed regional groups that were already in place at the "bottom", thus causing a [[circular argument]].
It was directly used to advocate [[slavery]] in the [[rhetoric]] of others [[Origins of the American Civil War|pre-Civil War]] [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrats]], that were struggling to maintain their grip on the [[Southern United States|Southern]] economy. They saw the [[Abolitionism in the United States|abolition of slavery]] as a threat to their powerful new Southern market that revolved almost entirely around the [[Plantation economy|plantation system]] which was furthered by the use of primarily [[Native ethnic groups of Africa|African]] slaves, but also utilized destitute [[Caucasian race|whites]].
These and other colloquialisms were used as rhetoric in what has been dubbed "the [[Marxism]] of the [[Slaveholder|Master-Class]]"<ref>Hofstadter, 1974</ref> which fought for the rights of the propertied elite against what were perceived as threats from the [[Abolitionism in the United States|abolitionists]], lower classes and non-whites to gain higher standards of living.
[[Abraham Lincoln]] argued forcefully against the mudsill theory, particularly [[s:Address before the Wisconsin State Agricultural Society|in a speech]] in [[Milwaukee, Wisconsin]], in 1859,<ref>[http://www.abrahamlincolnonline.org/lincoln/speeches/fair.htm "Address before the Wisconsin State Agricultural Society," Milwaukee, Wisconsin, September 30, 1859]</ref> where he delineated its incompatibility with [[Free Soil]]. In his view, mudsill advocates "conclude that all laborers are necessarily either hired laborers, or slaves", since to them, "nobody labors unless somebody else, owning capital... induces him to do it". Further, mudsillers believed that these laborers were "fatally fixed" in their status. Lincoln contrasted his view that labor was in fact the source of capital, noting that a majority of persons in [[Free state (United States)|Free States]] were "neither hirers nor hired", but in such professions as farming where they worked for themselves.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8bWmmyJEMZoC |title=Lincoln on Democracy |author=[[Abraham Lincoln]] |year=2004 |publisher=[[Fordham University Press]] |isbn=0-8232-2345-0}}</ref>
Northern soldiers fighting in the [[Western Theater]] of the Civil War turned this derogatory term into one of self pride, as in "Western Mudsill".
